items.name: Basic
items.description: The following functions are used to provide basic functionality to HUDs, like changing the display's position and drawing things.

invocations.description: Sets the top-left corner of the display to position x and y. Use this to define the placement of the display on the screen. All elements added will be situated relatively to this position.
invocations.exDescription: Will draw a text showing your current health at position x: 305, y: 505.

invocations.description: Returns a table with the x and y coordinates of the display.
invocations.exDescription: Will draw a texting showing the current position x, y of your HUD script.

invocations.description: Will set the ARGB color for the border to be drawn around shapes. If you don't want a border for shapes pass -1 as the color. This function also sets the border color for texts, if a border width has been specified in the setfontstyle function.
invocations.exDescription: Will draw a rectangle with a white border.

invocations.description: Sets the composition mode for blending objects/text. The default composition mode is 3 (source). You can read more about composition modes here.
Adds any amount of ARGB colors to a gradient, each at position ranging from 0.0 to 1.0.
invocations.exDescription: Draws a 60x40 rectangle  using gradients. The colors will go from 'dark grey' to 'light grey'.

invocations.description: Fills the drawn shapes with color color.
invocations.exDescription: Draws a circle with diameter 40px. It will be filled with a 'light grey' color.

invocations.description: Fills the drawn shapes with image imagename (ex: image.png) located in the /images/ folder.
invocations.exDescription: Will draw a 60x60 rectangle filled with the image 'mypicture.png'.

invocations.description: Fills the drawn shapes with minimap data starting at startx, starty and transparency level transparency (255 is fully transparent). The zoom parameter may be specified to draw the minimap closer or further, a zoom value of 1.0 will make it draw 1 SQM/pixel, value of 0.5 will make it draw 2 SQMs/pixel, and so on.
invocations.exDescription: Will draw a 100x100 semi-transparent rectangle filled with the minimap data from your current position offset'ed by 50 SQMs to the left and 50 SQMs to the top.

invocations.description: Fills the drawn shapes with a linear gradient. spreadtype can be 0 (PadSpread), 1 (ReflectSpread) or 2 (RepeatSpread).
invocations.exDescription: Draws a 100x100 rectangle using gradients drawn diagonally, the colors will go from a 'light pink' to 'red'.

invocations.description: Fills the drawn shapes with a radial gradient.
Fills the drawn shapes with a conical gradient.
Draws a rectangle starting at position x, y, with width width and height height. The rectangle will grow to the bottom and to the right.
invocations.exDescription: Draws a 60x40 rectangle, starting at position x: 25, y: 25.

invocations.description: Draws a rectangle with rounded corners. xradius and yradius specify the radius of the ellipsis defining the corners of the rounded rectangle.
invocations.exDescription: Draws a 50x50 rectangle, starting at position x: 25, y: 25. The corners will have a radius of 4 pixels horizontally and 4 pixels vertically.

invocations.description: Draws an ellipsis with horizontal diameter width and vertical diameter height.
invocations.exDescription: Draws an ellipsis with diameter 30x50.

invocations.description: Draws a line with width width and height height starting at position x and y.
invocations.exDescription: Will draw an horizontal line of width 50.

invocations.description: Draws a pie that starts at startangle and goes for spanangle degrees.
Draws a chord that starts at startangle and goes for spanangle degrees.

Draws an item from the game with id id at position x: x, y: y. The value zoom is used to resize the outfit, if you pass it as 100, it will draw without any resizing, 50 will draw it with 50% the size, and so on. You can also specify an amount to draw, for stackable items. If you set phase to -1 it will animate the image.
invocations.exDescription: Draws an animated fire sword.

invocations.description: Draws an outfit from the game with id id at position x: x, y: y. The value zoom is used to resize the outfit, if you pass it as 100, it will draw without any resizing, 50 will draw it with 50% the size, and so on. dir is the direction to where you want it to look to, ranges from 0 to 3. You may specify a phase phase, if you pass -1 to it, it will animate the drawing making it walk. You can also specify the headcolor, chestcolor, legscolor, feetcolor and addon. You can also specify a mount with id mountid
invocations.exDescription: Draws a worker golem looking to the south and makes a walking animation to it.

invocations.description: Sets properties to the texts that will be drawn by the script. fontname is the name of the font. fontsize is the size of the font. color is the color of the font. fontweight is use to determine if you want to draw it as bold. semi-bold or normal. bordersize is the width of the border that will be drawn around the texts. bordercolor is the color of that border. glowradius is used to draw texts with a glowing effect. glowcolor is the color used on the effect.
invocations.exDescription: Will draw a text displaying your current mana using the font 'MS Serif', with size 10, color white and bold text.

invocations.description: Sets the font name to fontname.
Sets the font coor to color
Sets the font size to size
Sets the font border to bordersize and bordercolor
Sets the font weight to weight. A weight of 50 stands for normal thickness, 75 is bold, and maximum value is 99.
Draws a text with the previously specified font style to the current display, at position x and y. This position is relative to the display's position (check setposition for more information).
invocations.exDescription: Draws a text displaying your character's current position at position 35x35 of your screen.

items.name: Positioning
items.exDescription: The following functions are used to position your HUDs relatively to some in-game element.

invocations.description: Calculates and returns the size that a text element will take using the currently set font, font size and font width. This returns 4 values: width, height and left, right, because sometimes fonts that are very decorated draw beyond the designated rectangle and at negative values.
invocations.ex:
local textToBeDrawn = 'Testing measure string'
local w, h = measurestring(textToBeDrawn)
drawtext(textToBeDrawn, 200 - w, 20 - h*0.5)
invocations.exDescription: Will draw a text aligning it to the left relatively to the position x: 200, and centering it vertically in the middle of an imaginary rectangle of height 20.

invocations.description: Returns a table with the coordinates of the rectangular area (.left, .right, .top, .bottom, .centerx and .centery) right below the health bar of the creature creaturepointer is drawn. It's position is relative to $worldwin.left and $worldwin.top.
invocations.ex:
auto(200)
setposition($worldwin.left, $worldwin.top)
setbordercolor(-1)

local r = getbararea($self)
if ( r ) then
	local mppc = $mppc/100
	setfillstyle('color', 0)
	drawrect(r.left, r.top, 26, 3)

	setfillstyle('color', 0x02266FF)
	drawrect(r.left + 1, r.top + 1, 24*mppc, 1)
end
invocations.exDescription: Draws a mana bar right below your health bar.

invocations.description: Returns a table with the coordinates of the rectangular area (.left, .right, .top, .bottom, .centerx and .centery) where the name of the creature creaturepointer is drawn. It's position is relative to $worldwin.left and $worldwin.top.
invocations.ex:
init start
	useworldhud(false)
init end

foreach creature c 'xs' do
	local r = getnamearea(c)
	if ( r ) then
		drawtext(c.name, r.left, r.top)
	end
end
invocations.exDescription: Will draw the player name right above the name drawn by Tibia. Try it yourself to understand it better.

invocations.description: Returns a table with the coordinates of the rectangular area (.left, .right, .top, .bottom, .centerx and .centery) for creature creaturepointer. It's position is relative to $worldwin.left and $worldwin.top.
invocations.ex:
setposition($worldwin.left, $worldwin.top)
local r = getobjectarea($self)
setposition(r.left, r.top)
drawtext('Hey hey', 0, 0)
invocations.exDescription: Will draw the text: 'Hey hey' at the top left edge of your character.

invocations.description: Returns the rectangular area of the tile at the position x:posx, y:posy, z:posz. It's position is relative to $worldwin.left and $worldwin.top.
invocations.ex:
setposition($worldwin.left, $worldwin.top)
local r = getobjectarea($wptx, $wpty, $wptz)
drawtext('W', r.centerx, r.centery)
invocations.exDescription: Will draw the letter 'W' at the center of the current waypoint.

items.name: List As
items.exDescription: The following functions are used to display the 'list as' texts of hotkey scripts, persistent scripts, etc.

invocations.description: Returns true if the script of type scripttype and index index is currently running, false otherwise. Possible value for scripttype are: 'hotkey', 'persistent', 'cavebot' and 'display'.
Returns the list name of the script with type scripttype and index index. The list name is the name of the script, or the custom string passed to the listas function.
Returns the list color of the script with type scripttype and index index. The list color is the default color of scripts, or the custom color passed to the listcolor function.

items.name: Settings
items.exDescription: The following functions are used to change the settings of your HUDs. These settings are used to improve the speed of the script, or to change some configuration based on your operational system.

invocations.description: Puts the HUD script into OpenGL rendering mode if enabled is true, or normal rendering mode otherwise. OpenGL should only be used for displays that refresh very quickly and/or are big in size, because it uses more memory and creating/resizing the display is slower. However, refreshing the display in OpenGL is much faster.
Choose whether to enable or disable the anti-aliased painting of rounded shapes to make them appear smoother. Keep in mind that this slows down rendering a little.
Sets the background color of the element to color. This function should only be used if you're using Windows XP.
invocations.ex:
init start
	if $windowsxp then
		setbkgcolor(0xFFFFFF)
etend
init end
auto(200)
setfontstyle('MS Serif', 9, 100, 0x000000)
drawtext('testing...', 0, 0)
invocations.exDescription: Will set the background color to white if you are using Windows XP, and will draw a testing text with color black.

invocations.description: Sets a fixed size for the display to size width and height. The reason to set a fixed size is to speed up rendering for displays that doesn't get resized a lot. Usually, it is faster to draw to a larger display than to have it resized frequently. If you can predict the size that your display will take, it is better to set a fixed size for it.
Kills a previously spawned hud window of id hudid and returns true if successful.

Sets the current hud to id hudid and returns true if the hud switch was successful. It is important that you only draw to this hud window if this function has returned true because newly created hud windows may take some time to become available for drawing onto. If hudid is 0, the main hud is set as the current hud and the function always returns true.
Spawns a new hud window that belongs to the current hud display script and returns it's id. The hud can be drawn to by calling setcurrenthud.

Will make the current hud script draw everything in the 'world hud' window. The 'world hud' window is refreshed in sync with the game's drawing. So if you are making a script that draws something in the world window you should use this, for example: magic wall timers, show great fireball areas, player information scripts, etc.
invocations.ex:
init start
	useworldhud()
init end

foreach creature c 'ps' do
	local r = getnamearea(c)
	if ( r ) then
		drawtext(c.name, r.left, r.top)
	end
end
invocations.exDescription: Will draw the player name right above the player name drawn by Tibia.

items.name: Input
items.exDescription: The following functions are used to provide interaction between HUDs and the user.

invocations.description: Enables or disables the filtering of input events through the inputevents(table e) function which must be defined in the init block of the current script. If keys is set to true, key presses on a HUD will call the input function with e.type IEVENT_KEYDOWN or IEVENT_KEYUP and e.value1 set to the virtual key code of the key. If mouseclicks or mousemoves is set to true, mouse clicks or moves on a HUD will call the input function with e.type IEVENT_LMOUSEDOWN, IEVENT_LMOUSEUP, IEVENT_RMOUSEDOWN, IEVENT_RMOUSEUP, IEVENT_MMOUSEDOWN, IEVENT_MMOUSEUP, IEVENT_MOUSEMOVE, IEVENT_MOUSEENTER or IEVENT_MOUSELEAVE and e.value1 & e.value2 will contain the local x, y positions of the event within the HUD, except for the last 2. For mouse clicks, e.elementid will contain the unique element id hit by the click which is returned by the drawshape function for each shape. If e.type is IEVENT_MOUSEWHEEL, e.value1 contains packed coordinates of the event and e.value2 contains a negative or positive delta value of the distance the wheel has traveled in either direction. If stealfocus is true, the HUD window will become focused after being clicked on and the client will lose keyboard focus. Focus is necessary to be able to capture keys.
invocations.ex:
init start
	local rectid = -1
	local ellipsisid = -1

	function inputevents(e)
		if e.type == IEVENT_LMOUSEUP then
			if e.elementid == rectid then
				print('Clicked on rect')
			elseif e.elementid == ellipsisid then
				print('Clicked on ellipsis')
			end
		end
	end
init end
auto(200)
filterinput(false, true, false, false)
setposition(200, 200)

rectid = drawshape('rect', 0, 0, 50, 50)
ellipsisid = drawshape('circle', 50, 110, 50, 50)
invocations.exDescription: Will a rectangle and an ellipsis on your screen, and set input events for them. If you click in any of them, a message will be printed on the console saying which one was clicked.

invocations.description: Requests an integer number from the user. This can only be called from the inputevents(table e) function. The question parameter is the question to ask the user and the default parameter is the default value to be shown. A request id can be specified in the requestid parameter. This request id will be passed to the inputevents function as the e.value1 parameter to identify later on what was requested. The e.type parameter will be IEVENT_REQUESTINT and e.value2 will represent the chosen integer number.
invocations.ex:
init start
	local reqid = 5
	local rectid = -1

	function inputevents(e)
		if e.type == IEVENT_LMOUSEUP then
			if e.elementid == rectid then
				requestint(reqid, 'Please, enter a value', 30)
			end
		elseif e.type == IEVENT_REQUESTINT then
			print('The user\'s answer was: ' .. e.value2)
		end
	end
init end
auto(200)
filterinput(false, true, false, false)
setposition(200, 200)

rectid = drawshape('rect', 0, 0, 50, 50)
invocations.exDescription: Will open an integer request when you click on the rectangle. When the user choose the value, it will print the value on the console.

invocations.description: Requests a decimal point number from the user. This can only be called from the inputevents(table e) function. The question parameter is the question to ask the user and the default parameter is the default value to be shown. A request id can be specified in the requestid parameter. This request id will be passed to the inputevents function as the e.value1 parameter to identify later on what was requested. The e.type parameter will be IEVENT_REQUESTFLOAT and e.value2 will represent the chosen float number.

Requests a text from the user. This can only be called from the inputevents(table e) function. The question parameter is the question to ask the user and the default parameter is the default value to be shown. A request id can be specified in the requestid parameter. This request id will be passed to the inputevents function as the e.value1 parameter to identify later on what was requested. The e.type parameter will be IEVENT_REQUESTTEXT and e.value2 will represent the text string.

Requests a text string out of a list from the user. This can only be called from the inputevents(table e) function. The question parameter is the question to ask the user and the defaultindex parameter is the default index in the list to be shown. A request id can be specified in the requestid parameter. This request id will be passed to the inputevents function as the e.value1 parameter to identify later on what was requested. The e.type parameter will be IEVENT_REQUESTLIST and e.value2 will represent the chosen or written text string. List items must be added using the requestlistitem function.
invocations.ex:
init start
	local reqID = 5
	function inputevents(e)
		...
			requestlist(reqID, 'Please, choose an item from the list', 0)
			requestlistitem('item1')
			requestlistitem('item2')
			requestlistitem('item3')
		...
		if e.type == IEVENT_REQUESTLIST then
			print('The item selected was: ' .. e.value2)
		end
	end
init end
...
invocations.exDescription: This example works just like the requestint example, but it requests a value based on a pre-made list. Also notice that some parts of the example was ommited to make the example smaller.

invocations.description: Adds the text option to a request list. This must be called after calling requestlist.

Requests a text string out of a popup menu from the user. This can only be called from the inputevents(table e) function. A request id can be specified in the requestid parameter. This request id will be passed to the inputevents function as the e.value1 parameter to identify later on what was requested. The e.type parameter will be IEVENT_REQUESTMENU and e.value2 will represent the chosen text string. Menu items must be added using the requestmenuitem function.
Adds the text option to a request popup menu. This must be called after calling requestmenu.
